mentions.context: CheckV, VirSorter2 and VIBRANT identified 3898, 3968 and 3904 viral genomes (6484 distinct genomes in total), respectively, with most of the genomes being linear, double stranded and predicted to belong to virulent viruses.

CheckV, VirSorter2 and VIBRANT identified 3898, 3968 and 3904 viral genomes (6484 distinct genomes in total), respectively, with most of the genomes being linear, double stranded and predicted to belong to virulent viruses.

CheckV, VirSorter2 and VIBRANT identified 3898, 3968 and 3904 viral genomes (6484 distinct genomes in total), respectively, with most of the genomes being linear, double stranded and predicted to belong to virulent viruses.
In the case of metaviromes, ViromeQC analysis moderate contamination rates of 7.6% and 8.8% for D13vir and D17vir, respectively.
MAG quality was improved with Refi-neM (Parks et al., 2017) and controlled with CheckM (Parks et al., 2015).
Coding regions were predicted with Prodigal (Hyatt et al., 2010).
Hosts were also predicted using the WIsH software (Galiez et al., 2017) to compare the genomic signatures of viral contigs to those of cellular MAGs.
All networks were computed using the igraph package of R (Csardi & Nepusz, 2005).
Sequencing data were processed with the Torrent Suite Software.
Viral genome detection was performed with CheckV, VIBRANT and VirSorter2.
Besides, 34 were predicted as virulent by VIBRANT and only one, C1485, was predicted as temperate (Supplementary Figure S5, Supplementary Table S5).
Viral genome detection was performed with VIBRANT (Kieft et al., 2020) and VirSorter2 (Guo et al., 2021), and the quality of viral contigs was assessed with CheckV (Nayfach et al., 2021).

The viral contigs were subsequently aligned with BLASTn and Space-PHARER (Zhang et al., 2021) against this homemade database and a public spacer database (CRISPRCasdb spacer: https://crisprcas.i2bc.paris-saclay.fr/Home/
All diversity analyses were performed with the R phyloseq package.
Viral genome detection was performed with CheckV, VIBRANT and VirSorter2.

The viral contigs were subsequently aligned with BLASTn and Space-PHARER (Zhang et al., 2021) against this homemade database and a public spacer database (CRISPRCasdb spacer: https://crisprcas.i2bc.paris-saclay.fr/Home/
The detailed parameters and versions for the python and bash scripts are presented in Supplementary Tables S2 andS3.
Viral genome detection was performed with CheckV, VIBRANT and VirSorter2.
Genes were annotated using comparison to NCBI nr database with Diamond (Buchfink et al., 2015).
In addition, protein sequences were compared to RefSeqVirus using MMseqs (bit score ≥50), retaining only the best hit for each protein of an OG.
Concerning the viral metagenomes, their quality was assessed with ViromeQC (Zolfo et al., 2019) based on the trimmed reads.
First, CRISPR spacers were detected in cellular metagenome contigs with CRISPRdetect (Biswas et al., 2016) and CRISPRCasFinder (Couvin et al., 2018).
Viral genome detection was performed with VIBRANT (Kieft et al., 2020) and VirSorter2 (Guo et al., 2021), and the quality of viral contigs was assessed with CheckV (Nayfach et al., 2021).
For each dataset, the cleaned reads were mapped to the assembled contigs using Bow-tie2 (Langmead & Salzberg, 2012) and counted with samtools (Li et al., 2009).
MAG quality was improved with Refi-neM (Parks et al., 2017) and controlled with CheckM (Parks et al., 2015).
Genome scaffold quality results were obtained through three different bioinformatic tools: VIBRANT, CheckV and VirSorter2: 35 contigs had low or medium quality.
Genome scaffold quality results were obtained through three different bioinformatic tools: VIBRANT, CheckV and VirSorter2: 35 contigs had low or medium quality.
Metagenomeassembled genomes (MAGs) were constructed from assembled cellular metagenomic contigs with Metabat2 (Kang et al., 2019).
Genome scaffold quality results were obtained through three different bioinformatic tools: VIBRANT, CheckV and VirSorter2: 35 contigs had low or medium quality.
First, CRISPR spacers were detected in cellular metagenome contigs with CRISPRdetect (Biswas et al., 2016) and CRISPRCasFinder (Couvin et al., 2018).
Several steps specifically dedicated to viral contig analysis and to host prediction were performed using homemade bash and python scripts.

After a pre-processing step (adapter removal, and trimming according to quality scores and length with fastp), reads were assembled with metaSPADES (Nurk et al., 2016) (individual assembly by sample for cellular metagenomes and coassembly for metaviromes).
Viral genome detection was performed with VIBRANT (Kieft et al., 2020) and VirSorter2 (Guo et al., 2021), and the quality of viral contigs was assessed with CheckV (Nayfach et al., 2021).
